articles.headline: Stocks Rally to Start Year; Will January Be an Omen?
articles.snippet: In 60 of the last 80 years, the performance of the S.& P. 500 in January has accurately predicted whether stocks would end higher or lower for the full year, one analyst said.
articles.abstract: In 60 of the last 80 years, the performance of the S.& P. 500 in January has accurately predicted whether stocks would end higher or lower for the full year, one analyst said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Among Wall Street’s many proverbs, traders say one stands above the others: “As goes January, so goes the year.”

articles.headline: Saving for College Amid the Financial Turmoil
articles.snippet: If a family puts too much money in stocks, it could easily lose a year’s worth of tuition in a matter of months.
articles.abstract: If a family puts too much money in stocks, it could easily lose a year’s worth of tuition in a matter of months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saving for college is one of the most vexing problems in all of personal finance.

articles.headline: Credit Card Companies Willing to Deal Over Debt
articles.snippet: Credit card companies are rushing to settle even if that means forgiving a portion of some borrowers’ debts.
articles.abstract: Credit card companies are rushing to settle even if that means forgiving a portion of some borrowers’ debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hard times are usually good times for debt collectors, who make their money morning and night with the incessant ring of a phone.

articles.headline: A Chinese Chef’s Long, Diverted Path to 3 Stars
articles.snippet: Chan Yan-tak, the first Chinese chef to earn Michelin’s top ranking, quit the industry to be a stay-at-home dad but was coaxed back.
articles.abstract: Chan Yan-tak, the first Chinese chef to earn Michelin’s top ranking, quit the industry to be a stay-at-home dad but was coaxed back.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The world’s big Michelin-starred names — the Robuchons, Ramsays and Ducasses — generally achieve success by breaking free of former employers and opening restaurants named for themselves, followed by offshoots, cookbooks, television shows and other trappings of the celebrity chef.

articles.headline: Desperate Retailers Try Frantic Discounts and Giveaways
articles.snippet: An era of desperation marketing is at hand as retailers adopt virtually any tactic that might grab the attention of frightened consumers.
articles.abstract: An era of desperation marketing is at hand as retailers adopt virtually any tactic that might grab the attention of frightened consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a dealership on the outskirts of Miami, people who agree to buy one Dodge Ram truck can get a second truck or car — free. In 415 supermarkets across the East, customers who bring in a prescription can walk out with free antibiotics. And one clothing chain, not to be outdone, has started offering three suits for the price of one.

articles.headline: Preaching Moderate Islam and Becoming a TV Star
articles.snippet: The religion-themed shows of a new generation of “satellite sheiks” have helped fuel a religious revival in the Arab world.
articles.abstract: The religion-themed shows of a new generation of “satellite sheiks” have helped fuel a religious revival in the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia — As Ahmad al-Shugairi took the stage, dressed in a flowing white gown and headdress, he clutched a microphone and told his audience that he had no religious training or titles: “I am not a sheik.”

articles.headline: Madoff Trustee Seeks Wide Power to Subpoena
articles.snippet: A request seeks unusual authority to subpoena witnesses and documents, citing the alleged Ponzi scheme’s scale.
articles.abstract: A request seeks unusual authority to subpoena witnesses and documents, citing the alleged Ponzi scheme’s scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of Bernard L. Madoff’s trading firm has made an urgent request to the court for unusually broad authority to subpoena witnesses and documents, citing the vast scale of what is alleged to be a $50-billion Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Launch Attack on Gaza
articles.snippet: Israeli tanks and troops swept across the border into Gaza on Saturday night, opening a ground war against Hamas after a week of intense airstrikes.
articles.abstract: Israeli tanks and troops swept across the border into Gaza on Saturday night, opening a ground war against Hamas after a week of intense airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli tanks and troops swept across the border into Gaza on Saturday night, opening a ground war against the militant group Hamas after a week of intense airstrikes.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Taghreed El-Khodary

articles.headline: Is the Real Target Hamas Rule?
articles.snippet: If Hamas rockets cannot be stopped, then is Israel’s real aim to remove Hamas itself, no matter the cost?
articles.abstract: If Hamas rockets cannot be stopped, then is Israel’s real aim to remove Hamas itself, no matter the cost?
articles.lead_paragraph: EREZ CROSSING, on the Israel-Gaza border  As Israel’s tanks and troops poured into Gaza on Saturday, the next phase in its fierce attempt to end rocket attacks, a question hung over the operation: can the rockets really be stopped for any length of time while Hamas remains in power in Gaza?

articles.headline: Portrait Emerges of Anthrax Suspect’s Troubled Life
articles.snippet: The investigation yielded nothing more than a strong hunch that Dr. Bruce E. Ivins was the perpetrator, a Times examination found.
articles.abstract: The investigation yielded nothing more than a strong hunch that Dr. Bruce E. Ivins was the perpetrator, a Times examination found.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREDERICK, Md. — Inside the Army laboratory at Fort Detrick, the government’s brain for biological defense, Bruce Edwards Ivins paused to memorialize his moment in the spotlight as the anthrax panic of 2001 reached its peak.

articles.headline: The Irish Economy’s Rise Was Steep, and the Fall Was Fast
articles.snippet: The Irish developer Sean Dunne, who became a symbol of the country’s boom, faces a foundering economy.
articles.abstract: The Irish developer Sean Dunne, who became a symbol of the country’s boom, faces a foundering economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dublin

articles.headline: For the Blind, Technology Does What a Guide Dog Can’t
articles.snippet: At Google, a blind engineer is a pioneer in customizing technologies that were not designed with blind users in mind.
articles.abstract: At Google, a blind engineer is a pioneer in customizing technologies that were not designed with blind users in mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.

articles.headline: Obama Considers Major Expansion in Aid to Jobless
articles.snippet: The Democratic economic package may include much more government-assisted health insurance and unemployment help.
articles.abstract: The Democratic economic package may include much more government-assisted health insurance and unemployment help.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  President-elect Barack Obama and Congressional Democrats are considering major expansions of government-assisted health care insurance and unemployment compensation as they begin intensive work this week on a two-year economic recovery package.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Israeli Attack Splits Gaza; Truce Calls Are Rebuffed
articles.snippet: Witnesses said that Israeli forces pushing into Gaza had taken over certain strategic areas as Hamas continued to launch rockets into southern Israel.
articles.abstract: Witnesses said that Israeli forces pushing into Gaza had taken over certain strategic areas as Hamas continued to launch rockets into southern Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON THE ISRAELI-GAZA BORDER — Israeli troops and tanks, protected by heavy air, sea and artillery fire, sliced through the center of Gaza on Sunday, taking control of rocket launching areas and surrounding the main city, as their government rebuffed diplomatic efforts to end the nine-day assault.

articles.headline: Richardson Won’t Pursue Cabinet Post
articles.snippet: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico withdrew as the commerce nominee amid a grand jury inquiry.
articles.abstract: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico withdrew as the commerce nominee amid a grand jury inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, President-elect Barack Obama’s choice for commerce secretary, withdrew from consideration for that job on Sunday, saying a pending investigation into whether his administration gave lucrative contracts to a political donor would have “forced an untenable delay” in his confirmation.

articles.headline: Auto Industry Still Coming to Grips With the Damage of 2008
articles.snippet: Each of the six largest automakers, including foreign and domestic brands, is expected to say that its sales in the United States fell at least 30 percent in December.
articles.abstract: Each of the six largest automakers, including foreign and domestic brands, is expected to say that its sales in the United States fell at least 30 percent in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Carmakers will close out one of the most tumultuous and miserable years in their history Monday when they report what is certain to be another dreadful batch of monthly sales figures.

articles.headline: A Star Turn for a Sheriff on Fox TV
articles.snippet: With his reputation for being tough on crime and his way with a good quote, Sheriff Joseph M. Arpaio of Maricopa County in Arizona would seem to be a reality show waiting to happen.
articles.abstract: With his reputation for being tough on crime and his way with a good quote, Sheriff Joseph M. Arpaio of Maricopa County in Arizona would seem to be a reality show waiting to happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his reputation for being tough on crime and his way with a good quote, Joseph M. Arpaio, the sheriff and jailer of Maricopa County in Arizona would seem to be a reality show waiting to happen.

articles.headline: Google Hopes to Open a Trove of Little-Seen Books
articles.snippet: Google’s book search may allow writers to make money from titles that have been out of commercial circulation for years.
articles.abstract: Google’s book search may allow writers to make money from titles that have been out of commercial circulation for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Ben Zimmer, executive producer of a Web site and software package called the Visual Thesaurus, was seeking the earliest use of the phrase “you’re not the boss of me.” Using a newspaper database, he had found a reference from 1953.

articles.headline: CNN Gets Buzz It Wants (if Not the Way It Wants)
articles.snippet: Resembling MTV more than a cable news network, CNN’s New Year’s Eve coverage included an eyebrow-raising performance by comedian Kathy Griffin.
articles.abstract: Resembling MTV more than a cable news network, CNN’s New Year’s Eve coverage included an eyebrow-raising performance by comedian Kathy Griffin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Acting not unlike many New Year’s Eve partygoers who pushed the revelry a little too far, CNN woke up on Jan. 1 with a tinge of regret.

articles.headline: Kidnappings in Mexico Send Shivers Across Border
articles.snippet: A string of kidnappings targeting people with family in the United States has caused many people to flee Mexico.
articles.abstract: A string of kidnappings targeting people with family in the United States has caused many people to flee Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: FELIPE ANGELES, Mexico — Four hooded men smashed in the door to the adobe home of an 80-year-old farmer here in November, handcuffing his frail wrists and driving him to a makeshift jail. They released him after relatives and friends paid a $9,000 ransom, which included his life savings.

articles.headline: As Vacant Office Space Grows, So Does Lenders’ Crisis
articles.snippet: Rising vacancy rates across the country could make it hard for building owners to pay their mortgages.
articles.abstract: Rising vacancy rates across the country could make it hard for building owners to pay their mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vacancy rates in office buildings exceed 10 percent in virtually every major city in the country and are rising rapidly, a sign of economic distress that could lead to yet another wave of problems for troubled lenders.

articles.headline: Gaza Hospital Fills Up, Mainly With Civilians
articles.snippet: Doctors have been battling to keep Shifa Hospital in Gaza City running under the most adverse circumstances, but scant resources are being stretched to a breaking point.
articles.abstract: Doctors have been battling to keep Shifa Hospital in Gaza City running under the most adverse circumstances, but scant resources are being stretched to a breaking point.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA  A missile hit their uncle’s house, which was made of concrete and so, the Basal family had thought in taking refuge there, safer than their more flimsy one. Fida Basal, 20, was not there when the missile struck Sunday, the day after Israel began its ground invasion of Gaza. But her sister, Hanin, 18, was.

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Superheroes Save the Day
articles.snippet: As companies big and small trudge into January after a dismal 2008, the movie business is quietly celebrating solid if not spectacular results at the multiplex.
articles.abstract: As companies big and small trudge into January after a dismal 2008, the movie business is quietly celebrating solid if not spectacular results at the multiplex.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  As companies big and small  if they still exist at all  trudge into January after a dismal 2008, the movie business is quietly celebrating solid if not spectacular results at the multiplex.

articles.headline: Obama Plan Includes $300 Billion in Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: The breaks for workers and businesses are nods to critics who are worried that the economic recovery program has been too focused on government spending.
articles.abstract: The breaks for workers and businesses are nods to critics who are worried that the economic recovery program has been too focused on government spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama plans to include about $300 billion in tax cuts for workers and businesses in his economic recovery program as he seeks to win over Congressional skeptics worried that he was too focused on government spending, advisers said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Blu-ray’s Fuzzy Future
articles.snippet: The demise of the HD DVD video disc format appeared to hand the future of home entertainment to Blu-ray, but struggles continue.
articles.abstract: The demise of the HD DVD video disc format appeared to hand the future of home entertainment to Blu-ray, but struggles continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest news at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last January was not the birth of a new product but the death of one.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brad Stone

articles.headline: Israel Deepens Gaza Incursion as Toll Mounts
articles.snippet: As European diplomats sought a cease-fire, Israeli troops poured into Gaza City, expelling residents and shooting militants.
articles.abstract: As European diplomats sought a cease-fire, Israeli troops poured into Gaza City, expelling residents and shooting militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON THE ISRAEL-GAZA BORDER  Israeli troops commandeered high-rise buildings in three eastern districts of Gaza City on Monday, expelling residents and shooting militants in the streets in their furious effort to break Hamas’s fighting ability.

articles.headline: Apple’s Jobs Explains His Weight Loss
articles.snippet: Steven P. Jobs said that he was being treated for a hormone imbalance but would remain in his job.
articles.abstract: Steven P. Jobs said that he was being treated for a hormone imbalance but would remain in his job.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple, sought to put to rest persistent speculation about his health on Monday, disclosing in a public letter that a hormone problem  and not a recurrence of cancer  had contributed to his very visible weight loss over the last year.
